title: 34.3 NP-Completeness and Reducibility
content:
Section 34.3

NP-Completeness and Reducibility

Summary

The hardest problems in NP.

Key Points

  • NP-hard: at least as hard as any problem in NP
  • NP-complete = NP-hard ∩ NP
  • Reduction: A ≤_P B means solving B solves A
  • If any NP-complete problem is in P, then P = NP
  • Cook-Levin theorem: SAT is NP-complete

Example

3-SAT ≤_P CLIQUE: convert formula to graph where clique exists iff formula satisfiable.

Why It Matters

Shows many problems are computationally equivalent - solving one solves all.
